awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract: Thermoelectric systems convert heat to electricity and vice versa. They have applications in refrigeration, waste heat recovery, and thermometry. With no gas or liquid components and no moving parts, thermoelectric devices are small, portable, and sturdy. However, the energy conversion efficiency of thermoelectric materials decreases with decreasing temperature. Therefore, to date, there is no efficient thermoelectric systems operating below ~ 200 K. The thermoelectric system this project is focused on fabricating and measuring, is predicted to be efficient at elevated temperatures. From a technology perspective, this will enable applications that were previously thought impossible such as thermoelectric cooling for cryogenic devices and space telescopes. This project trains a new generation of students with expertise in quantum systems, synthesis, characterization, cryogenics, low-noise electronics, and computation. Undergraduate research and recruitment of underrepresented groups is facilitated through Colorado School of Mines' bridge program with community colleges. Additionally, modules are being developed, introducing the science behind this project, for use in Mines' outreach programs to Denver Public Schools, Vertical Skills Academy (which is a school for dyslexic children in Evergreen, CO), and the community.

Technical abstract: Thermoelectric effects, which are normally negligible in superconductors, are expected to increase dramatically in superconductor (S) - ferromagnet (F) hybrids. Although exciting theoretical predictions abound, there are hardly any experimental studies in this field. Moreover, there are no studies, experimental or theoretical, on the role of dimensionality and the nature of superconductivity (singlet vs. triplet). This is a tremendous missed opportunity for several reasons. First, if the predictions of high thermoelectric figure of merit at cryogenic temperatures are correct, S-F systems will be the only efficient thermoelectrics in this temperature range. Second, there is fascinating Physics at S-F interfaces, including triplet superconductivity, seen in charge and spin transport measurements. Thermoelectric effects offer a novel probe into this Physics. Third, the effects of reduced dimensionality on quasiparticles in a superconductor, which are relevant for thermal effects, has not been explored. Finally, there are a number of fascinating predictions for thermal effects in S-F systems that have not been realized because the 'groundwork' experiments are missing. This project fills this gap by systematically investigating thermoelectric effects in S-F hybrids using low-temperature, charge, spin and thermal transport measurements. The results test existing theoretical predictions, inform future studies and explore heralded applications including nanoscale cooling. These efforts build upon the PI's expertise in nanoscale fabrication and low temperature transport experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

por.por_cntn:
Superconducting-ferromagnet hybrids exhibit fascinating properties due to their conflicting spin orders - superconductors require electrons to have anti-parallel spins while ferromagnets favor parallel spins. This inherent conflict has spurred extensive research into the electronic and spin properties of these hybrids. However, despite numerous theoretical predictions suggesting intriguing thermal effects, thermal measurements remain relatively rare. This research project addressed this gap by investigating thermal effects in superconducting-ferromagnet hybrids. In particular we investigated a predicted giant thermoelectric effect in these hybrids. Here is a breakdown of the key achievements:

Intellectual Merit

A new technique for creating niobium nanowires using a template-based electrodeposition process was developed (Figure 1, [1]). This method is advantageous because Nb is a valuable superconductor with a relatively high critical temperature but, has a high melting point, making deposition with traditional methods challenging.

We created two types of resistive thermometers suitable for cryogenic applications (extremely low temperatures): Focused-ion beam deposited (FIBD) thermometers (Figure 2, [2]) and focused electron-beam deposited (FEBD) thermometers. Both thermometers can be deposited directly on the substrate without additional lithography steps with a resolution of 100s of nanometers and have sensitivities comparable to state-of-the-art ruthenium dioxide thermometers at sub-Kelvin temperatures. These thermometers are likely to find applications in a variety of experiments.

Using these thermometers, we did a systematic exploration of on-chip thermal gradients generated as a result of electrical heating [3].

Finally, we measured the thermoelectric effect in these hybrids down to 100 milliKelvin. In particular, we measured the Seebeck coefficient, which is the voltage generated due to a temperature gradient and is correlated with how good a thermoelectric any material is. This measurement was performed for the components of our superconductor-ferromagnet hybrid structure separately – aluminum and nickel - and then for the aluminum-nickel hybrid (Figure 3). The Seebeck coefficient of the aluminum and nickel was consistent with what has previously been measured at higher temperatures. The hybrid did not reveal evidence of the predicted giant Seebeck effect. This finding provides valuable data for refining theoretical models used to predict the behavior of these systems. By incorporating these realistic material properties, future predictions can achieve greater accuracy.

The research team is actively involved in disseminating their findings through publications (3 published, 1 in preparation) and presentations (5 invited, 4 contributed, 1 poster) at various conferences.

Broader Impact: New technology was developed for measurement of thermal effects at sub-Kelvin temperatures and novel measurements were made. The project has provided valuable training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and even high school students. 3 graduate students (who have now graduated) and 6 undergrads have been funded through this grant. They have acquired skills in micro- and nanofabrication, cryogenics, and electrical measurements in addition to valuable experience in project management, team work, and scientific communication. Four educational outreach modules were developed to improve understanding of relevant scientific concepts, such as superconductivity and quantum superposition, in students with learning difficulties (e.g., dyslexia) [4-7]. The learning outcomes of these modules have been measured and found to be positive (Figure 4). The modules are hosted on a publicly accessible repository.

 

References:

 

All names in bold are students in the PI’s group

 

[1] K. Blagg, T. Greymountain, W. Kern, and M. Singh, “Template-based electrodeposition and characterization of niobium nanowires”, Electrochemistry communications 101, 39-42 (2019). 10.1016/j.elecom.2019.02.011

[2] K. Blagg, P. Allen, T. M. Lu, M. P. Lilly, and M. Singh, (2020), “Focused ion beam deposited carbon-platinum nanowires for cryogenic resistive thermometry”, Carbon 169, 482 (2020). 10.1016/j.carbon.2020.06.087

[3] K. Blagg, A. Castagnede, and M. Singh, “On-chip heating effects in electronic measurements at cryogenic temperatures'', Cryogenics 126, 103536 (2022). 10.1016/j.cryogenics.2022.1035367

[4] S. Saiter, A. Faricy, C. Snow, M. Monroe, E. Pinsky, and M. Singh, “Understanding electrical transport and superconductivity: a module developed for hands-on learning”, (2023) – in the process of being uploaded to the Mines’ public repository.

[5] K. Blagg, P. Allen, J. Briggs, Y. Liu, C. Koh, R. T. Collins, and M. Singh, “Quantum Tic-Tac-Toe: A module developed for hands-on learning", (2021). 10.17605/OSF.IO/5J2PG

[6] C. Pierce, P. Allen, G. Smith, R. T. Collins, C. Koh, B. Moskal, and M. Singh, “Thermal transport: conduction and radiation: a module developed for hands-on learning", (2019). 10.25676/11124/173082

[7] K. Blagg, Y. Liu, W. Schenken, B. Moskal, M. Singh, C. Koh, and R. T. Collins, “Patterning by Light: the Engineering of Integrated Circuits", (2019). 10.25676/11124/173099

 

 


Last Modified: 04/03/2024
Modified by: Meenakshi Singh
